title: The Kosciuszko 2019: Victorem the punters’ pick in $1.3m race
text:
Racing editor Ray Thomas and the team discuss the weekend's big races, including The Everest and Caulfield Cup.

For quite some time now, Victorem and Noble Boy have been battling it out for favouritism for the $1.3 million The Kosciuszko (1200m) at Royal Randwick on Saturday.

But it’s Jenny Graham’s horse Victorem who has been well supported to win the race in the past week.

The past two Country Championships winners were around the $4 mark in the $1.3 million feature race for the past two months but the punters have come for Victorem and he’s set to start a $2.50 favourite.

Noble Boy is $4.80 for the race but his trainer Todd Blowes is bullish about his chances.

“The preparation has been faultless this time in,” Blowes said.

“In other preparations he’s had some muscle issues. But this time he’s ticked all the boxes and he’s as good as I can have him so I can’t wait for the race.”

Noble Boy and Victorem met in the winter over 1200m at Eagle Farm with the latter winning and putting a 2½ length gap between the pair.

Blowes thinks a few changes will help his horse reveres that result.

“The track won’t be anything like it was when we met Victorem last time. That track was extremely hard which threw things in Victorem’s favour,” Blowes said.

“Hughie also knows our horse well after winning three times on him. Looking at the speed map, I don’t think we’ll have a problem.

“Everything that has drawn outside him will be forced to go forward so we won’t have too many dramas. And he’ll have his chance to get out and get rolling.

“If we can beat Victorem it puts us in good stead for aiming for a stronger race. To be the first horse to do the Country Championships/Kosciuszko double would be pretty special.”

Blowes thinks Notation is the next hardest horse to beat in the race while Graham knows her five-year-old has something the others don’t.

“If he’s on-song I’d say he does have the best turn of foot in the race,” Graham said. “Noble Boy is a very good horse and like most of the horses that are in the race, you can’t disregard any of them.

“I think it’s in the lap of the Gods now. I’m very happy with my horse.”

The booking of star jockey Tommy Berry only adds to Victorem’s chances and he’s ridden him in a trial to get a feel for the horse. They’ll jump out from the ideal barrier five.

Graham also has Awesome Pluck, who ran third in the race last year, lining up again and he’s good value at $14.

“Like last year, I feel that he’s going into it under the radar,” Graham said. “I think he’ll run a super race. If he settles he’ll run very well.”
